question: How do machine learning approaches improve drug discovery, and what are the current limitations?

expert_sources.title: Highly accurate protein structure prediction with AlphaFold
A Deep Learning Approach to Antibiotic Discovery
Machine Learning in Drug Discovery: A Review

key_findings.finding: AlphaFold solved protein structure prediction, enabling structure-based drug design at scale
ML models can predict molecular properties (toxicity, solubility, binding affinity)
Generative models can propose novel drug candidates with desired properties
ML-discovered compound halicin showed novel antibiotic activity
Clinical trial success rates remain low despite ML advances (~10% from Phase I to approval)
Data quality, domain shift, and lack of negative data limit ML effectiveness

known_counterarguments.argument: ML predictions often don't translate to clinical success
known_counterarguments.validity: Valid, in vitro/in silico to clinical gap is large

known_counterarguments.argument: Training data doesn't represent novel chemical space
AlphaFold doesn't directly enable drug discovery
known_counterarguments.validity: Partially valid, still need to understand dynamics and binding

areas_of_uncertainty: True impact on drug approval rates

must_include: Clinical trial failure rates as limitation
bonus_points: Comparison of ML vs traditional approaches
